qas.question: When was the Endangered Species Conservation Act passed?
How did the Endangered Species Conservation Act benefit endangered species?

answers.text: by prohibiting their importation and subsequent sale in the United States

qas.question: What did the Endangered Species Conservation Act add to the wildlife definition of the Lacey Act?

answers.text: mammals, reptiles, amphibians, mollusks and crustaceans

qas.question: What two reptiles were particularly of interest for the inclusion of "reptiles" in the Endangered Species Conservation Act?
What important precedent did this set for invertebrates?

answers.text: This law was the first time that invertebrates were included for protection

qas.question: What is the identification number for the Lacey Act?

plausible_answers.text: to reduce the rampant poaching of alligators and crocodiles

qas.question: Why were mammals added to the protected species list?
When was the Lacey Act passed?

plausible_answers.text: mammals, reptiles, amphibians, mollusks and crustaceans

qas.question: What was excluded in the 1969 law?

context: The <b5_0>Endangered Species Conservation Act<b5_0/> (<b6_0>P. L. 91-135<b6_0/>), passed in <a0_0><b8_0>December, 1969<b8_0/><a0_0/>, amended the original law to provide additional protection to species in danger of "worldwide extinction" <a1_0>by prohibiting their importation and subsequent sale in the United States<a1_0/>. It expanded the Lacey Act's ban on interstate commerce to include <a2_0><b9_0>mammals, reptiles, amphibians, mollusks and crustaceans<b9_0/><a2_0/>. Reptiles were added mainly <b7_0>to reduce the rampant poaching of <a3_0>alligators and crocodiles<b7_0/><a3_0/>. <a4_0>This law was the first time that invertebrates were included for protection<a4_0/>.
